meanings.meaning: to water an animal, imbibe, drink up, fill with liquid, saturate
to shrink (fullers shrinking their cloth in water)
to feed (enable metal to enter the mold in metal casting)

to soften (in metals, to make more malleable, tractable, or liquid; in painting, to blend the colors, shades, or shadows to create a more lifelike effect; in drawing, to blend in order to give an illusion of volume to a round form. The various meanings of "adoucir" are interchangeable to a degree, and all tend toward "tempering" and "mollifying" (as COT1611 also gives), that is, bringing a material or process toward a new, more desirable or useful balance among its qualities, or in its outcome)
to smooth (see Yijun Wang and Pamela H. Smith, "Fat, Lean, Sweet, Sour: Sand of Ox Bone and Rock Salt,"  https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_012_fa_14)
burnt copper (cuprous oxide, a red pigment)
to fit with a stock, to mount (artillery)
brittle (of metals; see Yijung Wang and Pamela H. Smith, "Fat, Lean, Sweet, Sour: Sand of Ox Bone and Rock Salt," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_012_fa_14)
aquamarine (a variety of beryl, and its color)
a needle's worth (of thread or similar)
lower part of the vault of a furnace
old peach variety from southern France and the Iberian Peninsula that looks like an apricot
awl (strong needle mainly used for leatherwork)
to mix, to bind (materials other than metals)
metal alloy, especially of gold or silver coin; also fine metal for bells
aloe (a group of plants secreting bitter juice used in medicine; may also refer to the juice itself)

alum de glace.alternateSpellings: alung de glace, alun de glace

meanings.meaning: glass alum; probably synonymous with rock alum

Alum de plume.alternateSpellings: alung de plume, alum de plume

meanings.meaning: feather alum (a mineral; possibly spalt, spar, or asbestos. Cotgrave has Alun de plume as "stone allum" or "itching powder," which can be steeped, pounded, and spun into thread to make long-burning candle wicks and matches)
a mineral, possibly the same as feather alum

Alun de glace.alternateSpellings: alum de glace, alung de glace, alum de glace

meanings.meaning: perfuming material from the sperm whale
primer powder, powder for the touch hole
Greek preposition, used in pharmaceutical recipes to mean "the same amount"
to feed, to lure, to bait
impostume (Cotgrave has "an inward swelling full of corrupt matter")
natural sand, arid or lean, in which the grains do not adhere together
billon silver (billon refers to a mixed metal used in coinage, consisting of gold or silver with a preponderating admixture of a baser metal)
the compound of ground silver with which gilding or “silvering” is done
orach (Atriplex hortensis), a type of plant
a salt, possibly sal ammoniac (ammonium chloride), called de armonic by the English, according to the author-practitioner.

artist (in this period, “artiste” could mean skilled artisan, a Master of Arts (the university title), and was just beginning to be used in the sense of “creative artist,” as it is today. We chose to translate as “artist,” but this older connotation of artisanal skill should be kept in mind)
part of the plank on which a sword is furbished
defined on fol. 119r as a type of sand found in Germany used for molding
seat (for gilding, whether water gilding on a layer of bol or on an adhesive layer for mordant gilding)
unit of measurement, equivalent to an ell, (2–4 feet)
Autan wind (a SW or SSW wind)
sandiver, glass gall, i.e., the saline dross that rises to the top of a glass melt
azure (the color, or various pigments of that color)
blue pigment, probably smalt (see Jo Kirby and Marika Spring, “Ms. Fr. 640 in the World of Pigments in Sixteenth-Century Europe," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_321_ie_19.)
jewel (mostly but not necessarily a ring)
a variety of barley, called pomole in Occitan, according to the author-practitioner
a French breed of water dog, employed for retrieving water birds in hunting
basan (sheep-skin tanned in oak- or larch-bark; distinguished from roan, which is tanned in sumac)
defined by the author-practitioner on fol. 95r as a stick on which a thunderstone is mounted; used to furbish swords
to batter, to mount the battery

in Ms. Fr. 640, this term refers to an impermeable layer laid down on cloth in order to paint the cloth without the paint soaking through (see Sumeyye Yar, "Painting in Oil on Taffeta II," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_062_fa_17)
flashing (in metal casting: a defect produced by the metal penetrating where it should not, especially at the joints of a multi-part mold)
piece of artillery also known as base or passevolant
billon (mixed metal used in coinage, consisting of gold or silver with a preponderating admixture of a baser metal)
one who makes and sells bibelots, i.e., small curios or trinkets
poorly fortified town, fort, or place
bistre (brown pigment derived from the tarry soot of burned, resinous wood and beechwood)
grain (cereal in general, not wheat as in modern French)
meaning uncertain. Could refer to a variety of grain or a way of processing it
bolting cloth (for sifting flour, powder, or other material)
to bolt (to pass flour, powder, or other material through a sieve)
bushel (a cylindrical vessel used for grain)
gallicized spelling of the Latin "bolus armeni" (armenian bole)

a status conferred by the French king in the Ancien Régime, from the late medieval period onwards, granting privileges and financial aid in exchange for military manpower and taxes. "Bonne ville" thus usually referred to a city of a certain size and degree of fortification
ring (standard part of the structure of a cannon)
ring of the mouth (“muzzle ring” in modern terminology)
ring of the breech (“base ring” in modern terminology)
ring in the middle (“trunnion ring” in modern terminology)
liquid dip used by goldsmiths to clean silver of tarnish (now often called “pickle” in English—a heated mixture of vinegar and salt)

workshop (the author-practitioner envisions this as a place of making and selling goods as well as trading knowledge; see Tianna Helena Uchacz, "The Spaces of Artisanal Experiment and Inquiry," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_304_ie_19)
arm defense comprising pauldron and vambrace, called a "brassart" in English in the nineteenth century
brazilwood (a red wood used for dyeing)
medicinal plaster for horses, made with armenian bole
small bugloss (Anchusa arvensis, a hairy herbaceous plant of the family Boraginaceae, typically with blue flowers)
a substance for whitening silver, probably a "pickle" for removing tarnish
frail (a kind of basket made of rushes)
quadran (something that is square in shape)
calamine (a mineral substance of unclear identity. In modern terminology, calamine refers to a zinc ore)
barrel (hollow instrument, part of a furnace)
cannon-perrier (also known as a stone gun)
cape, sleeveless cloak, or woman's cap
thick paper upon which painters draw
papier-mâché, in the sense of pulped paper (see Tenzin Dongchung, "What is Carton?” https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_061_fa_17)
full charge (paper case containing shot—but no powder charge—that goes into the barrel of the gun)
casemate (fortified chamber, often projecting from a wall)
a pot or vessel, often used for boiling; possibly "posnet" as per Cotgrave, i.e., a small metal pot or vessel for boiling, with a handle and three feet
cavity, hollow (female mold or concave part of the mold that forms the relief in the molded object)
a kind of secondary mold; a cast of something which in turn will be used as a mold
ash from Acre (alkaline ash from St. Jean d'Acre in the Levant used in glassmaking)
calcined chalk and charcoal that crucibles are made of; and shop sweepings (dross, etc.) in a goldsmith's shop
method of melting and purifying metals in ashes
blue pigment, azurite ash (see Carl Garris, "What is Azur in Ms. Fr. 640?" https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_060_fa_17)
blue pigment, possibly azurite ash (cf. Kirby et al., s.v. azur de cendre; see Carl Garris, "What is Azur in Ms. Fr. 640?" https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_060_fa_17)
literally "camel;" a long stick on which the sword is laid down and attached for furbishing
watering pot (earthenware tool similar to the spout of a watering can)
helmet (the top part of an alembic)
crust (a crust-like covering or surface deposit that can appear when casting metal)
cope (the top mold in molding a bell, figurative from the ecclesiastical vestment)
coals or embers of a fire
pit coal (charbon de pierre and charbon de terre were used interchangeably at this time for the material known in English as pit coal)
to overcharge, to run too violently (like a military charge)
to saturate (ink), to charge (dye, possibly adding weight to the silk), to apply or cover (gilding and metalwork)
violent fire, power of fire, expulsion of fire (amount of powder in an arquebus)
grape variety from the Charentes region; one of two types of grape that the author-practitioner singles out for growing in tight bunches suitable for sugar casting
to heat (to raise the temperature of an object; can be contrasted with cuire and recuire)
to give a heat (used by goldsmiths, glass-makers and iron workers)
coppersmith, tinker, or kettle maker, depending on context
defined on fol. 12r as fullers' earth, used for casting in Ms. Fr. 640. According to Cotgrave, an astringent earth used in medicine
chafing dish (a vessel to hold burning charcoal or other fuel, for heating anything placed upon it; a portable grate)
unit of measure: a Parisian half-pint, according to Cotgrave "almost as big as our whole one"
royal cement (per Cotgrave, an excellent cement, or solder, used by goldsmiths)
modelling wax (the author-practitioner defines it as "white wax mixed with plenty of ceruse or blanc de plomb")
thread of wax, i.e., a sprue used in casting (the wax sprue forms a channel by which the metal flows into the mold)
vein of wax, i.e., a sprue used in casting (the wax sprue forms a channel by which the metal flows into the mold)
chisel, or scissors when used in the plural
to chase (to repair the surface of a cast)
small serrated chisel (a sculptor's tool, also known as gradine or claw chisel)
cittern (an instrument of the lute family)
civet (a substance taken from the glands of the civet-cat)
light and clear (as opposed to heavy or dense)
a sheet of gold or gilded metal
cushionet, or a small cushion, perhaps a technical term for a goldsmith's cushion
flour glue (made of wheat flour, also known as stationer's paste)
paste glue (also known as paste, wheatpaste, or flour paste)

fish glue (also known as mouth glue or water glue, since it can be moistened and made adhesive by wetting with the mouth; see Xinguo Wang, "Making and Using Fish Glue," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_056_sp_17)
hide glue (glue made from collagen-containing remains of four-footed animals, esp. the skin)
strong glue (probably made from collagen-containing remains of four-footed animals, e.g. skins, hooves, etc.)
columbine (a red-violet color similar to the neck of a pigeon)
colophony (solid residue left in the distillation of resin; defined also as pix graeca on 3v)

to counterfeit (i.e., to mimic a material using a different material, e.g., counterfeit jasper made from horn. The author-practitioner distinguishes this term from imiter, which he uses to mean making a representation of a thing, e.g., a rose from horn shavings)
cupel (a small flat circular porous vessel with a shallow depression in the middle made of pounded bone ash, pressed into shape by a mold, and used in assaying gold and silver with lead)
a similarly-shaped moveable hearth of the reverberatory furnace in which silver is separated from lead by cupellation
gold ground into microscopic particles from pulverised gold leaf; ground in a mortar with honey or gum water; see guineau2014, 519
cornaline (semi-precious red to flesh-colored stone now usually known as cornelian or carnelian)
horn (a translucent material, most likely bovine horn in the context of Ms. Fr. 640, which grows in layers that can be split into thinner sheets)
thickness (see Jenny Boulboullé and Maartje Stols-Witlox, "Corps in Ms. Fr. 640," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_307_ie_19)
currier (one whose trade is the dressing and coloring of leather after it is tanned)
general wadding or stuffing material; in rare instances, the cotton plant itself
to pour, to run through (sometimes in the sense of straining or filtering)
a substance to make metals flow more easily, a flux or liquefier (from French couler, "to run")
bastard culverin (gun weighing 35 quintals and armed with a 25 pounds cannonball)

copperas (sulfates of copper, iron, or zinc, distinguished as blue, green, and white copperas, respectively. While it belongs etymologically to the copper salt, "copperas" in English use has most commonly (and now exclusively) applied it to green copperas when undistinguished by attribute or context. Green copperas (sulfate of iron, ferrous sulfate, and green vitriol) is used in dyeing, tanning, and making ink)

toadstone (petrified tooth of the earless seal, originally thought to come from the head of the toad. It was used as a precious stone, and to detect the presence of poison. See Béla Demeter, "From Bestiary to Shop Manual," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_500_ad_20)
filth (possibly the scale resulting from excessive heat when melting metal)
imported clear cristallo glass from Venice, or a generic term for a more common clear glass known as vitrum blanchum
Literally "crocus of iron," made by dissolving iron filings in nitric acid or vinegar (used in Ms. Fr. 640 as an additive to mold materials to make the mold stronger and retain heat)
meaning uncertain; possibly a slip of the pen or corruption of crayons
cuirass (a defense for the torso, consisting of breastplate and backplate)
to cook (transform by the action of heat)
to damask (to apply to cloth patterns in the style of damask; see Yuan Yi, "Damasked Cloth," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_031_fa_15)
to decrepitate (to calcine or roast a salt or mineral until it no longer crackles in the fire)
to rid of grease or impurities; to degrease, or make lean or clean (as fullers do in fulling cloth)
to macerate, allay, or soften, by steeping; also to thin
demi-culverin (gun weighing 30 quintals and armed with a 20 pounds cannonball)
unit of currency (1/12 of a sol, 1/240 of a livre)
unit of weight (1/785 of a kilogram)
wares (from denerée ware which has the value of a denier)
tooth (wolf or dog tooth, used as a tool for burnishing gold and silver)
to lay tree roots bare in the winter; to take off shoes
a grinding tool that works on a wheel to polish the inside of pewter dishes and bowls (perhaps a lathe-like tool)
to release (i.e., as a mold releases the cast)
design or drawing, e.g., fols. 62r and 131r

to temper (i.e., according to OED2008, to bring to a proper or suitable condition, state, or quality, by mingling with something else; to qualify, alloy, or dilute by such mixture or combination; to mix, mingle, blend (ingredients) together, or (one ingredient) with another, in proper proportions. Based on a perception that a balance for the proper state of a material or of the human body should ideally be achieved)

to distemper (referring to a painting technique that involves a protein binding media such as egg, glue, or size; not to be confused with modern tempera, which refers more narrowly to using egg yolk as the binding medium)
at discretion, as much as is needed
a jewel made of two pieces joined together

sweet (of wine, foods, metals; see James Buckley, "Tin and its Uses in Ms. Fr. 640," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_070_fa_18, and Yijung Wang and Pamela H. Smith, "Fat, Lean, Sweet, Sour: Sand of Ox Bone and Rock Salt," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_012_fa_14)
measurement unit denoting a hand's breadth, or the breadth of four fingers
drug, any substance used as an ingredient in various making processes

rock water (defined by the author-practitioner on fol. 11r: eau de roche, qu’ilz appellent, c’est une eau distillée des mines où l’azur ou vert d’azur se trouve, qui naturellement distille par les veines de la montaigne ou qui est par alambic distillée par des pierres mineralles d’azur ou cuivre – "it is a water distilled from mines where azure or vert d'azur is found, which distills naturally through the veins of the mountain or is distilled through an alembic from mineral stones of azure or copper")

Eau de vie.alternateSpellings: eau de vye, eau de viye

meanings.meaning: eau-de-vie, i.e., distilled wine, such as brandy, or spirits
water in which bread has been boiled
aqua regia ("royal water," thus called because of its ability to corrode gold)

electrum, an alloy of gold and silver thought to have occult properties such as protection from poison (see Vera Keller, "Ancient and Modern Things in Ms. Fr. 640," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_331_ie_19.)
to imbibe (to be absorbed, soak in)
to imbibe (to be absorbed, soak in)
to helve (set on a haft or handle)
a measurement equivalent to a handspan, ca. 25 cm
to slot (something into a groove or notch)
the space between, or middle part (used by the author-practitioner to mean a band of clay employed in lifecasting turtles)
to model (wax; see Fabien Noirot, "Molding, Modeling, and Repairing," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_504_ad_20)
scale, especially in metal working (the scales that form as a blacksmith hammers iron, which fall to the floor of the forge, and are used in diverse processes)

scarlet (in both French and English, this was usually a rich red color but could refer to other colors. Could also refer to cloth of this color, usually of a very high quality, and worn ceremonially by high-ranking officials)
to break, to burst, to crack
hammering process aimed at making metals harder and denser, often translated in English as "hammer-hardening"
quillon block (part of the hilt of a sword)
escutcheon (shield or lozenge shape, especially a mark on a cannon which may indicate the powder charge)
hanter en escusson = shield grafting (a method of grafting trees)
to scratch (creating a pattern in satin by a technique akin to pinking; see Nicole Bertozzi, "Pinking Satin," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_078_fa_18)

a blue pigment, possibly smalt, azurite, or verditer (see Jo Kirby and Marika Spring, “Ms. Fr. 640 in the World of Pigments in Sixteenth-Century Europe,” https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_321_ie_19.)
enamel of a red-violet color similar to the neck of a pigeon
gules red enamel (an opaque red enamel, cf. transparent rouge clair enamel; see Amy Chang, "What is Esmail in Ms. Fr. 640?" https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_038_sp_16)
emery (hard stone used in powder form for polishing)
spinet (small keyboard instrument with plucked strings)
to wipe, to dry, to cleanse
looking-glass tin (tin alloy used for backing glass mirrors)
a little square iron box for melting tin (used by locksmiths according to the author-practitioner)
tammy cloth (used for straining or sieving)
thin laths usually made of beech wood traditionally used to make sword sheaths
tow (fiber of flax, hemp, or jute, prepared for spinning by some process of scutching)
breach (made by an explosive, e.g., a petard)
falconet (according to the author-practitioner, a cannon 10 pans long weighing four quintals, with shot weighing 1.25 lb, and a powder charge of half a lb)
meaning uncertain, possibly a kind of wool cloth known as "wadnall" in contemporary English
closure (the closing part of a clay contour)
figure (where clearly referring to a material object)
figurated (decorated with human or animal figures as opposed to abstract ornaments)
thread of wax, i.e., a sprue used in casting (the wax sprue forms a channel by which the metal flows into the mold)

Fil de cire.seeAlso: cire, filon de, cir, fil de, filon de cire

meanings.meaning: vein of wax, i.e., a sprue used in casting (the wax sprue forms a channel by which the metal flows into the mold)

Filon de cire.seeAlso: cire, filon de, cir, fil de

meanings.meaning: fine (in the case of metals, this can mean pure; in other cases it is often unclear whether it refers to quality or purity)
flower (the whole plant or the bloom)
meaning uncertain; according to Cotgrave, "a thunder-stone, a kind of stone wherewith Cutlers furbish their blades”
florey (indigo pigment from the dark blue foam and scum on the surface of the woad or indigo dyeing vat)
meaning uncertain; likely related to feuillage, which can refer to ornamentation resembling foliage (on fol. 39v, it is used in the context of champlevé enameling)
violent fire (fire that is blown up into live flames, e.g., by opening all the flues of a furnace)
founding (the process, e.g., of founding a cannon)
borer (a boring tool larger than a gimlet)
a very hot furnace, or kiln
reverberatory furnace (using reflected heat, with the fire separated from the hearth; the chamber can reach very high temperatures without the material catching fire)
furnace fanned by the wind, as opposed to a four a souflets (bellows furnace)
furbisher (sword-cutler, one who assembles and furbishes swords; see Jonathan Tavares, "Arms and Armor in Ms. Fr. 640," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_308_ie_19)
possibly barbers' oven (used for heating towels)
to pill (i.e., to remove the husk or shell of beans, grains, etc.)
defined on fol. 94v by the author-practitioner as ceste escaille de fer tombant a la forge des mareschaulx, "the iron scale falling at the farriers' forge."
fusion, i.e., melting of glass or metal at very high heat
a tool for furbishing (i.e., polishing and removing rust from sword blades)
fustet (a subspecies of sumac whose yellowish wood is used for medicines and dyes)
gabion (a large basket-like container filled with rocks and used as protection for gunners)
galipot (turpentine or resin which exudes from, and hardens upon, the stem of certain pines. Not to be confused with the English “gallipot,” a vessel used in alchemy)
madder (Rubia tinctorum, plant source of a red dye and pigment)
gate (in casting, the opening in the mold into which the molten metal is poured)
jet (a hard black variety of coal that takes a brilliant polish and is used for jewellery, ornaments, etc.)
to glaze (with oil paint to achieve a glassy surface)
egg glair (egg white, often beaten with water and then strained, used as a pigment binder)
a type of vessel (according to Cotgrave, an earthenware bowl, cup, or jug)
gum ammoniac (also known as “ammoniac gum” or ammoniacum. A complex gum/oil/resin mixture obtained from the stems of the carrot family plant, Dorema ammoniacum, native to Iran and India)
tragacanth gum (a natural gum obtained from the dried sap of several species of Middle Eastern legumes of the genus Astragalus)
meaning uncertain, possibly lower quality gum (gomme + -iche suffix for lower quality)

according to Cotgrave, grais/grès means either 1) a kind of stone used for paving and (in powder form) for polishing; or 2) a particular type of potters' clay or earth for making stoneware vessels as well as the stoneware vessels themselves. In the context of Ms. Fr. 640, this material is used to make crucibles and molds for tin casting, and so it is more likely a stone (perhaps similar to schist or sandstone) which was used by pewterers for casting dishes; see nadolski1986

great metals (it is unclear which metals this refers to; on fol. 32v, the author-practitioner lists gold, silver, copper, latten, and iron, but on fol. 134v writes of the casting of gold, and on fol.156r, of lead “and the other great metals")

fatty (soft, malleable, or rich, according to material or context; see Yijung Wang and Pamela H. Smith, "Fat, Lean, Sweet, Sour: Sand of Ox Bone and Rock Salt," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_012_fa_14)
the name of a steel tool used by a sword furbisher to polish and sharpen the sword blade (from the verb gratter, to scratch)
scratch-brush (either a large wire brush or a small, pencil-shaped brush now commonly used in clockmaking)
a type of tin ingot (described in Ms. Fr. 640 as smaller, more processed, and more convenient to sell than the saulmon)
name given to several species of squirrel and, by extension, to their fur
a grey pigment, probably made from blacksmiths' iron scale
coarse, thick, large (of sand, cloth, etc.)

large wares (in this period, grosserie often also referred to work done in bulk (see Littré), but this is not what seems to be implied in Ms. Fr. 640. See also Cennini's use of grosseria as opposed to minuteria, suggesting large wares as opposed to small delicate ones. Cennini’s translator Ashbee: “metal work of the larger sort, as opposed to minuteria. Our term, hammered hollow ware, would partly express it. It mainly included the beating of large vessels into shapes, but it did not exclude the processes of casting”)

guede woad (as distinct from pastel or "pastel woad"; it is unclear whether the author-practitioner means the two terms to be entirely synonymous. Cotgrave: “Many of the French dyers call the courser sort of stuffe Guesde, and the finer Pastel; most writers confound them”)

pig (in metalwork, a large ingot of iron cast straight from the blast furnace. In English, the term "pig" is still widely used and includes iron and non-ferrous materials cast into sand or metal molds, provided that it is intended for remelting before use. In French, gueuse is restricted to virgin iron)
gimlet (a small tool with a screw point, grooved shank, and cross handle for boring holes)
alidade (pivoted sight or pointer, typically part of an astrolabe)
hackbut (used interchangeably with "arquebus" in the period; Cotgrave also has “caliver,” which is a small smooth-bore long firearm)
arquebus à croc, or wall gun (a gun with a hook preventing the recoil by steadying it on a wall or battlement)
haqueton (a now obsolete English term designating a jerkin or plated leather jacket)
meaning uncertain, perhaps strong-box or coffer (on fol. 163r, it refers to a specific quantity of amber, possibly a coffer's worth)
meanings.references: DMF2015, DMLBS (Dictionary of Medieval Latin from British Sources), Ducange

meanings.meaning: ben oil (derived from the Moringa tree, an aromatic used in perfume)
oil of sulfur, oil of vitriol (sulfuric acid)
unidentified substance that is added to molten metals to make them run more fluidly through a mold, and also causes them to change color (hence perhaps its name, literally "tinting oil")

to imitate (the author-practitioner apparently distinguishes between imiter and contrefaire, with imiter meaning to make a representation of something (a thing or scene), and contrefaire to mimic a (valuable) material in (more available) materials, such as coral contrefaict and jaspe contrefaict)
impalpable (used in casting as a technical term for a powder ground so fine that no grit can be sensed when rubbing it between the fingers)
imprimatura (i.e., OED: "a thin priming or ground, frequently coloured, applied to an artist's canvas or panel")
a shade of red (Cotgrave: "a deep, rich, or bright carnation")

a literary word, essentially meaning "dishonourableness" (a similar word, "honorificabilitudinitatibus," is used in Shakespeare’s Love's Labour's Lost, Act V, Scene I, and other sources, including fifteenth- and sixteenth-century dictionaries. In Ms. Fr. 640, the term is used like "abracadabra" in a sleight of hand trick on fol. 34v)
injection (not necessarily intravenous injection, but any administration of liquid medicine into any part of the body, such as an enema)

oriental jacinth, a precious stone that resembles a ruby (Corneille1694: "Pierre pretieuse, qui par son feu semble tenir du rubis. Elle en differe pourtant en ce que sa couleur est moins chargée; elle ressemble aussi à l’Amethyste, tirant quelque peu sur le violet.... Toutes ces sortes de Pierres sont Orientales, apportées de Cananor, Calecut ou Cambaïe.")

Floral Games (annual poetry contest organized since 1323 in Toulouse by the Consistori del Gay Saber, known today as the Académie des jeux floraux. The prizes are lifecast flowers, usually made of silver: a marigold (first prize), wild rose (second), and violet (third). See Colin Debuiche and Sarah Muñoz, "Le contexte toulousain," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_312_ie_19)
double handful (the amount that can be cupped in two hands)

natural day (24 hours), in contrast to a jour artificiel (a tradesman’s day from sunrise to sunset), or jour civil (also 24 hours, but starting and ending according to the custom of the place or nation)
having perforations or holes, pierced (specifically designating an ornamental openwork pattern)

Literally "old K.," likely an abbreviation for a coin such as the "Carolus" (a base silver coin marked with a letter K) or the German Kreuzer (abbreviated as K and made of silver-copper alloy up until the seventeenth century). The term occurs twice in Ms. Fr. 640 (fols. 86v and 147v), in association with a silver-copper alloy

latten (a copper alloy containing tin, zinc, and sometimes lead. While often assumed to be identical to "brass" today, in early modern Europe the precise composition of common copper alloys (such as laiton, latten, brass, and bronze) was not fixed nor was latten necessarily considered an alloy separate from—or inferior to—bronze)
potin latten (presumably latten made with potin, an alloy of copper and tin, usually with lead and zinc, used to make coins by ancient Celtic peoples)
plate (of metal. In plated armor, overlapping plates or bands connected by rivets or internal leathers to achieve articulation)
sheet (of metal, thinner and/or smaller than a lame or "plate")
tool used to charge guns, or the equivalent measure of powder
lake (pigment, extracted from natural dyestuffs; usually red. From lac, a red colorant made from a variety of organic materials)
dried lake pigment, formed into a flat shape for storage and sale
dried lake pigment, shaped into round beads for storage and sale
a type of lead ingot (in Ms. Fr. 640, it appears to be smaller, more processed, and more convenient to sell than the saulmon, a large ingot or mass of unprocessed metal straight from the furnace)
to wash (for pigments, this refers to a process now known as levigation)
residue (of gold or silver, recovered from ashes, sweepings, and crucibles in a goldsmith's workshop)
female lizard (usually qualified as being small)
bundle (a quantity of glass for sale)
line (often a measurement; Cotgrave says a twelfth of an inch; on fol. 22r it is defined as a twelfth of a king's foot)
roll or strip of fabric, band
litharge (a lead-based pigment, today commonly referring to yellow lead oxide, but historically also used for red lead oxide or white lead carbonate)
livre (any of a number of coins or units of account used in France)
loop (mass of raw iron from the smelting furnace, also called "bloom")
lute (clay or cement composed of various ingredients used to stop a hole, coat vessels to protect them from the fire, or seal a joint between pieces of apparatus, e.g., for distillation)
to lute (cover the outside of the vessel with lute to seal and protect the vessel from the heat)
liquid binder used in sand molding
lean (sand, earth, etc.; see Yijun Wang and Pamela H. Smith, "Fat, Lean, Sweet, Sour: Sand of Ox Bone and Rock Salt,"  https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_012_fa_14)
mandore (small stringed musical instrument. The derivative mandorle could also refer more generally to the shape of an almond, a term used by Vasari to describe certain ornamental motifs)
marble (sur le marbre used to mean "on the marble slab," e.g., of grinding)

marcasite (bronze-yellow mineral consisting of iron disulfide, also known as pyrite or "fool's gold." Bernard Palissy defines marcasites as imperfect metals, sometimes formed in a square fashion, like dice)
meaning uncertain, could refer to the "cascabel," the projection behind the breech of a muzzle-loading cannon
excess reserve of liquid metal for filling a mold
a yellow pigment (today referring to a pale yellow lead monoxide, but historically referring to lead-tin yellow)
mastic (a resin excreted in tears by <i>Pistacia lentiscus/<i>)

possibly a wild peach (Prunus persica Batsch. In Ms. Fr. 640, peaches are generally called pesches, the big yellow fruit also known as “pavie” in modern French and often just called "peach" in English (vs. "melicotony" used in English in the eighteenth century)
a specific variety of copper alloy (in Ms. Fr. 640, used in bells and petards, among other works)
meaning uncertain, seems to refer to an additive which makes tin look like silver

great metals (unclear which metals this refers to:  on fol. 32v, the author-practitioner lists gold, silver, copper, latten, and iron, but on fol. 134v writes of the casting of gold, and on fol. 156r, of lead “and the other great metals")
bread pith (the inner part of a loaf)
millet (a variety of common barley, of which is made a very coarse bread, particularly in the South of France)
measure of grain and dry goods between 110–120 English pounds or half a setier
mine, source, quarry, or cave dug in the ground
minium (red pigment, usually referring to red lead oxide)
Possibly a variety of minium, or a lead ore
minium (red pigment, usually referring to red lead oxide)
debris (in particular of brass and copper)
grindings from sharpening (powder of stone and metal particles left over from sharpening metal tools on a whetstone)
pincers (i.e., a pair of pincers used as a tool)

meaning uncertain, likely a "moresque" ornament, imitating Ottoman fabrics (By itself, the word is used for forms found in ornament and decoration in the applied arts in Europe. In early seventeenth-century English, it could more specifically mean a grotesque ornament. See Ana Estrades, "Jasper Imitation on Horns," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_028_fa_15)
morion (open-faced helmet with cheek pieces and a brim, with either a comb or a point on top)
mortar (grinding tool, as in mortar and pestle)
petard (artillery. Mortier and the English “mortar” refer to an artillery piece which fires at high angles, but the author-practitioner also uses mortier for a bomb known in English as a petard)

type of sand used for molding (a byproduct of sharpening knives and scissors, as described on fol. 71v; it occurs twice on fol. 73r, where the scribe has left it blank and the author-practitioner has filled in the word)
The word could not be traced (appears to refer to some kind of device to hold molds in place)
to die (for colors, in the sense of fading away); to die down (in the context of a fire)

musket (also means a sparrowhawk, a small bird of prey, deriving from the French. The name was probably first given to small artillery pieces before it came to denote a hand-held, long-barrelled firearm. See, e.g., falcon)
to shed (of an animal with fur)
muid (i.e., a large vessel or measure)
nature, the natural, natural disposition, innate property or quality (see Isabella Lores-Chavez, "Imitating Raw Nature," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_045_fa_16)
niello (decorations on silver in a black enamel made of lead, copper, silver, and ammonia salt)
meaning uncertain; likely a black pigment (in Ms. Fr. 640, it seems to be specific to painting on glass)
black pigment (possibly made from hammer scale, known as scales black in English)
peach black (pigment made by charring peach stones and grinding into a powder. Percarum Lapidum refers to the prepared peach stones)
unidentified black pigment, possibly based on pit coal
walnut (often used as an approximate measure for an amount of material "the size of a walnut")

noyau is used in Ms. Fr. 640 to mean “core,” that is, the inner block in a mold that allows casting a figure with a hollow core or center (another name for such a “core” in French is âme. Félibien and Cellini use the two terms interchangeably (anima and nocciolo in Italian). The author-practitioner uses âme once on fol. 124r to mean core, but seems to contrast it to the noyau, by which he seems to mean the outer plaster mold. He contrasts molding and casting en chassis with that done en noyau, meaning molding with plaster either in one- or multi-piece molds)
young bud of a tree (in grafting)
to anoint (in the sense of greasing of smearing with an unguent)
type of chisel, for fine engraving or chasing
tinsel (leaf metal imitating a more precious material; in Ms. Fr. 640, brass or copper leaf imitating gold)
gold color (sometimes meaning a gold color produced by a particular process)
spangle gold (a type of gold which could be found by panning around Toulouse)
pistolet gold, coin worth half a pistole
mordant gilding (see Njeri Ndungu, "What is Or Mat?," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_041_sp_16)
amalgam gilding (a process in which mercury is mixed into a paste with ground gold, painted onto metal, and then heated, leaving a thin layer of gold on the metal as the mercury evaporates)
someone who works with precious metals in general
orgue (assembly of several gun barrels mounted on a rack)

elm (tree whose roots boiled in wine produce a binding medium for sand; see Caroline Marris and Stephanie Pope, "Sand Molds of Ox Bone, Wine, and Elm Root," https://edition640.makingandknowing.org/#/essays/ann_020_sp_15)
orpiment (bright yellow pigment made from arsenic trisulfide, also known as orpin)
a small plank (in Ms. Fr. 640, often of wood)
meaning uncertain; likely refers to a plant with palmately lobed leaves (perhaps the cut-leaved dead-nettle, Lamium hybridum, or the castor oil plant, Ricinus communis)
possibly a medicine (made of pig's tallow and palmately lobed leaves. Also used as an additive to enhance the drying capacities of oil)
handspan, unit of measure in the South of France (the distance between the ends of the thumb and little finger, ca. 25cm)
unit of measure for the sale of plate glass (on fol. 20r, a panier contains 24 plates and sells for 10 or 12 livres)
thick paper used for making cards, and also rough paper used to wrap merchandise

pappus, modified calyx (the part of an individual floret that surrounds the base of the corolla tube in flower heads of the plant family Asteraceae. On fol. 124r, suggested along with dandelion as a particularly difficult test of lifecasting ability)
fuller (a profession employed in finishing cloth using fine clay)
to fumigate (when dealing with molds and metals)
akin to; or to be kin to, or related to in nature
to pass (in heating iron and steel, this can mean heating the metal to cause them to pass from one color to another)
small type of cannon, also called base

pastel woad (the author-practitioner distinguishes pastel from guesde. Cotgrave calls it “Dyers woad (of a finer sort then that which is called Guesde),” and in the entry for Guesde, Cotgrave comments that “most writers confound them")
Caltha palustris, a variety of buttercup (ranunculus family)
variety of peach native to the Gers
hanger of a scabbard, attaching it to the belt (also known as a frog)
to penetrate, to reach all the smaller parts of a mold
dead arsemart, dead culerage, ciderage, peachwort (on fol. 72r, refers to a running agent or a kind of flux added to liquify or clean metal)
peck, unit of measure (of about 5 pints, used to measure oats)
pleasure pieces (guns not intended to be put on carriages)
king's foot, unit of measure (a standard 12-inch foot)
exact meaning unclear, but is used as a synonym for grais in Ms. Fr. 640 (According to Guy Miège, it means "a decay'd stone, a stone long since hewen out of the rock")
magnet (in modern chemical nomenclature, siderite is an iron carbonate mineral, also called chalybite)
paintbrush (not to be confused with brosse, which can be a flat brush)
pint (French or Parisian pint as a measure of volume, or a vessel containing that measure)
pistolet, a gold coin (often the Spanish escudo or doble escudo, but can be any gold coin)
a specific type of plane called a draw knife (described on fol. 95v)
a tool for burnishing tin plates (described on fol. 30v)
to plant, or to arrange or set (such as arranging animals for lifecasting on a slab of clay)
slab of earth or clay (on which animals being arranged for lifecasting are set)
thin piece of metal or wood
slab (in Ms. Fr. 640, used for preparing for lifecasting)
in clockmaking, this refers to a device for scoring cogs evenly (on fol. 82r)
Dutch quill (a quill that has been heated before the fire or in sand in order to harden it)
to smooth with pumice, to polish
to pounce (to transfer a design by pricking a pattern with a pin and marking through the pricked holes with powdered charcoal, chalk, or similar)

defined by the author-practitioner on fol. 94r in the context of sword construction as an "iron strip which closes off the branch which is at the end of the ricasso to stop thrusts from sliding into the guard"
porphyry (in Ms. Fr. 640, often refers to the porphyry slab used as a grinding surface)
cutting-punch (tool for punching and cutting out pieces of metal plate)
pipe that directs the air from the bellows through the tuelle (blast-pipe) and up into the furnace
to draw, to portray, to depict
putty (meaning either a powder or a paste)
an alloy of copper and tin, usually with lead and zinc, formerly used in the manufacture of coins
a large mushroom that often grows overnight

a form of the philosophers' stone, i.e., an alchemical powder projected over metal to transmute it into a nobler metal, such as gold (according to Cotgrave, "powder of projection, or of the Philosopher's stone; tearmed thus (in derision, and) because much gold hath beene wasted in the searching for it; thence also, any cousening, or iugling powder")
thumb, a unit of measure (not to be confused with an inch)
horsetail reed (used for polishing and sanding, e.g., of gessoed panels)
to prick, leaving a mark on marble with a knife
to set (of plaster, cement, and the like)
to give a good hold (used in Ms. Fr. 640 to describe the consistency of sand used for frame casting)
fine powder used for priming a gun
aurum musivum, aurum mosaicum, mosaic gold (a yellow metallic powder composed of a mixture of tin, sulfur, mercury and sal ammoniac)
type of well operated with one or more wheels
term designating several measurements (according to Cotgrave, a quarter of a pound, the fourth part of a hundreth, a Pinte, the "halfe of an Emine," or "a Quarter of the Moone")
tail (of an animal or a sword)
tang of a sword (the spike-shape extension at the end of a sword blade by which it is affixed to the hilt)
pomace (the grape skins, stems, etc., left over after pressing)
realgar (yellow mineral pigment composed of arsenic disulfide related to the pigment orpiment, also known as ruby sulfur, or ruby of arsenic)

to transform again by the action of heat (on fol. 111r, the author-practitioner defines recuire as the process of turning a mold red for the second time, faire pour la seconde fois rougir. He contrasts this process to drying (desseicher) metals. Similarly, in a marginal note on fol.118v, recuire is defined as “turning a frame red,” a process similar to what “is done for gold and silver”)

to anneal (a specific heat treatment which craftsmen use in order to “perfect their craft” or “make it more durable.” Goldsmiths, for example, restitute the desired malleability and ductility of their objects by reheating or annealing them. Glassblowers use a special furnace to reheat the glass to prevent it from shattering. This process is known as “annealing” or “tempering” in English. See Ashbee’s translations of “ricuocere” in Benvenuto Cellini’s Two Treatises)
rammer (for packing gunpowder into the gun barrel when loading a gun)
regulus (piece of metal separated from a mineral or ore by smelting or reduction as the first stage of purification)
to repair the surface of a cast
to retrace (to follow an existing line with another medium)
to take away or remove something from something else
term for small glass beads which could be colorless or tinted (for enameling, those with the least coloring were normally recommended for use)
to moisten, wet, or sprinkle with dew (a Latinism for moisten found on fol. 161v)
meaning uncertain; likely a pink pigment made with materials thought to have come from Alexandria (perhaps Alexandrine ruby found on the banks of the Nile)
method of enameling red glass on gold

A red pigment used in glass painting which the author-practitioner calls “the red from Germany” (ecailles means “scales” and often refers to metal scoria, perhaps suggesting a metal or mineral origin of the pigment)
red in body (probably in the sense of opaque red)

sand (in Ms. Fr. 640, refers to powders of various sorts used to make sand molds. It is also used to denote a mixture of plaster and refractory material for molds made with liquid plaster, which are distinguished from molds made from pure plaster)
sand bank or sand gravel (type of geological formation where one finds a deposit or concentration of gravel and sand usually due to erosion)
cobalt oxide of a blue color (sometimes used for making cobalt glass, a blue sapphire glass that was ground to make smalt and used as a pigment)
sandarac (a hard resin excreted from Tetraclinis articulata, a conifer tree in Algeria, used in varnish production and pharmacy)
dragon's blood (red resin excreted from a number of trees colloquially known as the “Dragon Tree,” of species including Dracaena and Daemonorops, and used as a pigment and in pharmacy)
sanguine (earth pigment of a hue ranging from brown to red)
to close, to hold (e.g., as in sand encasing a flower)
sausage (in Ms. Fr. 640, used to describe a cloth tube filled with gunpowder, serving as a fuse for a petard)

a large ingot or mass of unprocessed metal straight from the furnace (see DMF2015. savary1741 notes that they were commonly used by merchants as ballast, taking their name from their shape which resemble the salmon fish. cf. latte and grille, which are smaller more processed ingots of lead and tin, respectively)
one of two types of grape that the author-practitioner singles out for growing in tight bunches suitable for sugar casting
sap of trees ("en sape" when the sap is rising)
small bristle brush used by goldsmiths
tiny bristle brush (diminutive of saye, i.e., a small bristle brush used by goldsmiths)
scribe (in Ms. Fr. 640, it seems to refer to letter-painters, sign-painters, or, more generally, mediocre painters)

stil de grain (yellow lake pigment from the German schüttgrün, typically made from buckthorn berries (genus Rhamnus or Frangula), but could be any number of other yellow dyestuffs. In Ms. Fr. 640, the plants used are weld (Reseda luteola) and dyer’s broom (Genista tinctoria))
white salt (uncertain whether of a particular kind. Perhaps refers to sol blanc, a white, calcareous earth mined particularly in Saxony)
type of salt (possibly sal ammoniac, ammonium chloride, called de armonic by the English, according to the author-practitioner)
likely refers to the scum taken off the top of vitreous matter before it vitrifies
vessel used to carry the wine harvest
fenugreek (popular name for the plant also known in French as fenugrec)
septier (a measure for diverse things, and therefore of diverse sizes; according to Cotgrave, physicians use the smallest, 3 ounces)
gold (literally "sun," the alchemical symbol for gold)
currency unit, 12 deniers and 1/20 of a livre (abbreviated "s")
sole (base or floor of a furnace)
to become porous, to fill with bubbles (in the context of casting, for example, when gases are mixed in and make the cast porous and brittle)
natural sulfur, also known as virgin sulfur
literally "breathing hole" (in Ms. Fr. 640, a vent in molds for casting)
tang (spike-shape extension at the end of a sword blade by which it is affixed to the hilt)
white powder (perhaps feldspar or gypsum, a chalk-like deposit, zinc, or a zinc alloy; possibly synonymous with spat, described in Ms. Fr. 640 as found in Germany, near Augsburg)
earth used for frame-casting (described by the author-practitioner on fol. 108r, possibly synonymous with spalt)
stavesacre (plant whose seeds are used against lice and mange)
a kind of granular limestone, or tufa
sublimate (material that has been sublimed, i.e., heated into a vapor, then condensed or precipitated)
to grind finely, or to make thinner
suffocation of the matrix (medical term used to designate female hysteria)

sandiver (also called "glass gall," per Cotgrave: "the fattie substance floating on glasse when it is red-hot in the furnace, and which being cold is as hard as stone, yet brittle, and easily broken")
used by the author-practitioner to refer to excess molten metal that is needed to fill the mold, but is not integral to the cast object
slab of glass for crushing colors
panel (a painting on wood and usually not on canvas)
taffer (a pigment usually obtained by roasting cobalt glance, white sand, or quartz; used in porcelain painting and enameling pottery to produce a blue color)
the mouth end of the scabbard
talc or talcum (hydrous magnesium silicate, a green-to-gray soft mineral)
to taper, to make tapering, of a wall
to sieve (for dry ingredients), to strain (for wet ingredients)
tellin (any marine bivalve mollusk of the genus Tellina)

Terra merita.alternateSpellings: terre emerita, terra emerita, terroy merita

meanings.meaning: turmeric ("terra merita" defined on fol. 148r as "racine de cucurme")
boulbène earth (usually found in the Garonne valley and essentially made of clay and sand)
founder's earth (mostly used by bell founders and made of reclaimed material from used molds, such as sand, clay, manure, hair, and brick dust)
umber (earth from Umbria, yellow brown pigment containing iron oxide)
fullers' earth (a fine clay used in finishing cloth)
founders’ earth (described in great detail on fol. 127v as a mold material)

Terre des fondeurs.seeAlso: terre bourre, terre bolvene, terre des fondeurs

meanings.meaning: unidentified type of earth (according to the author-practitioner, is used by potters and can be added to casting sand for strengthening molds)
presumably a specific shape or kind of dish
theriac (a medicine made by mixing several ingredients such as plants or animal parts)
cake (a firmly pressed ball or slab)
an inner verrill (the round plate of iron whereby a piece of wood, often turned on, is preserved from wearing, and burning)
cake (a firmly pressed ball or slab)
crosswise (used to qualify molding and casting. Seems to refer to a technique of orienting the gate in a mold, characteristic of metalworkers in Foix)
possible meanings include a trap for animals and a small set of scales for weighing coins (either could apply in the context of Ms. Fr. 640, which suggests a thin item made of metal)
tempering (the process of quenching a heated metal in liquid)
tempering bath (the liquid used for quenching)
to temper (metals), to quench (as part of the tempering process)
tempering process for hardening metal of tools (e.g., files)
triblet (a disc on which goldsmiths set rings or other round objects to file or work them)
tripoli (silica stone, the powder of which is used to polish metals and glass)
blast-pipe (the conduit at the bottom of the furnace or kiln through which the bellows’ pipes are inserted)
tutty (a medicinal stone or dust made of crude zinc oxide)
quill or pipe (in the sense of a ferrule)
described on fol. 9r as a formulary for merchants' apprentices listing the prices of merchandise
to buff enamel with fine sand
vapor (fol. 157v refers to a method of blowing into a mold to remove ashes; the DMF2015 describes vapeur as either dry or humid)
to ventilate, to free from chaff by winnowing
probably “verdigris,” as it used in a context of casting potin
another name for the bird called ortolan (according to the author-practitioner)
color (likely a green mineral chalk, earth)
verdigris (copper green composed of copper acetate)
rod that painters rest their hand upon when they paint (in the sense of maulstick)
technique of enameling on a metal ground

glassmaker (in the Parisian context, a profession which produces glass objects, first recognized in 1583 in the Statutes of Paris, as contrasted with another group of glassworkers, the “vitriers,” who made flat plate glass, stained glass windows, and painted on glass)

unidentified green or green-blue pigment (according to the author-practitioner, is found in mines and is perhaps similar in composition to other mineral blues such as azurite (a copper carbonate). Cotgrave glosses vert d'asur as "A certain blewish greene stone, found in Mines of Copper which be mingled with silver, and an excellent purger of melancholie")
green verditer (a basic copper carbonate known as an artificial malachite because it is manufactured rather than found as a mineral in nature)
strap hinge (the word is found in eighteenth-century documents from lower Poitou-Charente)
blister or bubble (used on fol. 36v in connection with blowing glass). According to Cotgrave, vessie can also mean a distilling vessel)
wimble (a boring tool similar to a gimlet)
gimlet (possibly an alternative Occitan name for the tool that the author-practitioner usually calls guimbelet)
contraction of vitis alba (probably referring to white briony, bryonia alba)

species of willow (often Salix viminalis, employed for basket making, wicker, and thatch, among other uses. It is the Occitan word for the French osier, cultivated along the Garonne. Sometimes called “withy” or “osier” in English)

glassworker (the profession that makes plate glass, stained glass windows, and paints on glass. In the Parisian context, the vitriers apparently engaged in a different range of glassworking than the verriers, who were first recognized in 1583 in the Statutes of Paris)
today refers usually refers to iron sulfate, but historically is also applied to sulfuric acid
common (on fol.100r, refers to an artisan who does things in a simpler way or lacks the appropriate tools)
